title: Before you cry OP
body:
Please, try to play the champion that stomped you.

In my opinion, and in my experience, I have always walked away with a profoundly better understanding of enemy champ mechanics after I give the respective champ a play (even in just a bots match).

So please, try this.  If you are struggling against {{champion:67}} , play {{champion:67}} .  Even if you only give it a shot once or twice, your understanding will grow and the way you treat {{champion:67}}  in layne will change for the better.  The same goes for {{champion:157}} , {{champion:238}} , {{champion:412}} , {{champion:53}} , {{champion:92}} , and all other champs that people seem to constantly complain about.

I'm not saying that there aren't some broken aspects to some champs - certainly that's the exact reason some champs receive nerfs.  I just believe that actually trying champs out will both alleviate the QQ on the boards and provide a better playing experience for you.  

**Cheers!**

> [{quoted}](name=Vianci,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=HEBiEki3,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2015-08-13T18:15:46.606+0000)
>
> But Vayne with hp scaling true dmg and Riven with AD scaling shield are still OP imo :P

That's basically her replacement steroid. Her only other steroid is her ultimate, which--while respectable--is average at best, even for an ultimate. Most (primary) Marksmen have an AS steroid above 50%, usually along with another steroid, significantly multiplying their innate damage scaling, but Vayne just has her ultimate and Tumble, which only affects one attack every 2+ seconds.

Yes, I know the exceptions to that AS steroid rule. Kog'maw only has +30%, but it's literally always activated unlike most, and his kit's power is mostly loaded in the active abilities. Varus' passive is a wonky +20/40% AS steroid that's basically nonexistent; frankly, he needs an Ashe-style kit tweak. Corki's kit lacks a common steroid, and instead deals bonus True damage and has innate Armor Shred. Lucian doesn't have a regular steroid, but has his attack/spell weaving combos that let him multi-attack for Tons of DamageÂ©. Caitlyn doesn't have any real steroid, other than her passive every few attacks, and could also use a bit of kit tweaking imo.

Just not even going to mention *that* one, considering the hate spewed about that particular marksman...

Anyway, point is, Vayne has her true damage instead of an AS steroid. It scales on health, because she's built to be more of a tank buster than the average Marksman, and Silver Bolts does that job very well.

*Having said that,* removing the flat damage on Silver Bolts would be a very logical nerf.
---
As for Riven, her shield scaling on AD doesn't really do very much for her. There is a grand total of **five** (5)--count them out, five--end-game AD items that provide direct defensive stats. Two of them provide MR (Mercurial and Malmortius), and three of them provide Health (Mallet, Trinity and Cleaver).

With the addition of Sterak's Gage, there will be six.

Health itself is not very powerful alone, especially since increasing the efficiency of %HP damage works against the user, and MR is completely useless against physical-focused champions. There isn't an AD/Armor item to make that shield's scaling very useful against most top-laners.

Her shield scaling on AD means that she has a defensive tool that *doesn't* increase her vulnerability to another damage type, and that doesn't force her to build a pure defense item to be able to withstand a fight. And if you look at *all* melee carry type champions, they *all* have defensive tools that make it possible to play without building pure defensive items.

They can **definitely** feel that way, especially if you get countered by them or if they get fed.  Totally understand.

Also I'm not sure about Riven because animation cancelling seems like a weird mechanic to allow a char to profit greatly from.

When I first started playing League of Legends, I would consistently get frustrated when champions would come out of the blue and do a ridiculous amount of damage and I not know what happened at all. Vayne, Master Yi, Riven, Katarina, Akali. I had problems with all of them until I played with them myself and learned what each of their abilities did. 

It made playing against them so much easier and it definitely saved me a lot of stress from not knowing what killed me.

**EDIT**: I still sometimes get away from team fights with 1-10 health and die anyway but those are different encounters entirely.
i have always though that the best way to counter a champion is to play with that champion. Undestanding how a champion works its the best counter play of all.

I used to think Nidalee was really stupid after her rework.
After playing her, the damage she gets from her (difficult to hit) spear is a good reward for actually landing it, and now I just try to dodge instead of complaining.

(still hits a little too hard imo)

I was also delightfully surprised to find out when I played her how difficult her spears are to land, which makes me question how I feel when I get hit by them at nuclear holocaust range - am i pissed that ability gets so strong, or am I sad that I completely failed to dodge? lol
I tried Riven in ARAM and she was a lot trickier than I thought it would be. Master Yi OTOH, was much easier than I thought he would be.

I did. I played Zed.

I won three games in a row, and killed a bunch of people 100-0 whenever I had my ult up.

The only thing I learned about Zed is 'he's actually still pretty strong' and 'try and get your jungler to help you.'

Did you learn to build armor?  Or to be aware of when his shadow is up?  Or to engage on him when it's down?  How about how to bait his q?  Or how to flash or otherwise escape his ult?  Maybe that he lands right behind you?  

All these things I learned by playing him.

+1 for celebrating the power of junglers though.  Love them, want them, need them <3

People who QQ aren't interested in justifying why the champion is a problem. They're just interested in justifying why they lost. Kind of like how people who use the 'you just haven't played the champ before' argument aren't interested in debating a champion's power. They're just interested in 'protecting' their champion from criticism.

While this is probably true in some cases, my OP wasn't an argument to protect any champs from criticism.  I simply stated that before you complain about xyz champs, play them.  You'll get better against them, making your play experience better.
